Most or arguably all of the negative aspects of social media can be directly tied to their advertising based business model. I believe a user paid-for subscription model can correct for a lot of this and theoretically provide a vastly improved experience.

I'm from Maui, but my immediate family moved during COVID. All the rest of my family is still there. Thankfully everyone is safe and has what they need. The fires completely destroyed Lahaina, and many other treasured parts of the island. Lahaina was my hometown.

Simple Vuln Management. 1) Find all assets 2) Vuln scan all assets 3) Prioritize fixing vulns

Technologically we’ve only recently been able to do #1 at scale, so #2 was largely impossible, and to that extent #3. We also lack scalability in #3 causing reluctance to doing #2. /1

I frequently get to speak with incident responders about what they’re seeing. Anecdotally, they’re telling me ~50% of breaches have something to do with a previously unknown asset — unknown to the breached organization. Others in IR seeing similar? 1/

In analyzing attack surface maps of various market segments, I'm noticing a notable uptick in cloud deployed assets as an overall percentage. A few years ago it was ~2-5% amongst the largest banks, retailers, healthcare, etc. Now, segment depending, it's in the teens or 20s.

Because they will flow somewhere.

~23 years of CVEs. Tens of thousands of new vulns published each year. Anyone ever analyze the characteristics of the vulnerabilities that are never exploited?

@GinPerigee I suppose that's plausible, but Im not sure how likely that would actually be. But, let's say you're right... I think it would be a win if we cleaned up the 'most exploited' list of vulns and forced the blackhat to retool.

@GinPerigee You're probably right. But at least we'd have a set of vulns, which is likely quite large, that we really don't have to worry much about. The for what remains, we can try for a differential analysis on what makes some vulns exploit worthy.
~23 years of CVEs. Tens of thousands of new vulns published each year. Anyone ever analyze the characteristics of the vulnerabilities that are never exploited?

"Something is better than nothing."

We hear this all the time in security, and I was never convinced it was true. The "something" could be useless. And if so, you'll get hacked anyway, so better to do nothing because at least it won't cost time and money. Get hacked for free.

In today’s political discourse about monetary and tax policy, the term “fair share” is often used. I can’t seem to find a  definition. And when I ask, the response is a lot of hand waving. 

Best I can tell, fair share just means “more” than whatever you’re currently paying.

“What if we made paying ransoms illegal?” Probably would result in a global rm -rf. Hey, maybe that’d erase the debt.

Once learning of my background in “hacking,” countless people have asked me if I ever thought about going to the “dark side.” Interestingly, I can't think of ANYONE in InfoSec I’ve known who turned criminal. Almost like our industry has a higher average morality than society.

We don’t [yet] have a list of what we’re protecting (assets/data) or what it’s running. No one really knows how any of it works. The environment changes constantly. The ratio of assets to defenders is widening. Dollars per asset to defend them is decreasing. Work cut out for us.
